text: ¡Bottle at Clubhouse BFD event. Pours clear golden, white head. Aroma is lots of tart lemon, apple, pear. Flavor is light lemon, tart pear, apple, citrus rind. Not bad. A little tart. Fine.
Rated in 2010 (Backlog) - Cloudy amber appearance with a large off-white head. Aroma is of citrus and light spice. Taste is of citrus, pepper and yeast.

750 ml bottle purchased a few years ago and shared with JStax. 2014 vintage, actually. Pours a mostly clear orange with a massive eggshell white head, frothy in texture, lacing the glass and settling into an uneven film. Musty funk, with lemon, leather, rye, caramel, cobwebs, and sweet pie crust. Some earth and grass and herbs in there. Subtle. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a funky, sweet mouthfeel that finishes dry. Good stuff. Liked this one better than the Baudelaire iO Saison.

750 ml bottle shared by phaleslu. Thanks! The beer is a hazy orange with a white head of foam. Huge head and strong retention. The aroma has notes of musty rye and funky, herbal notes. Big body and sticky mouthfeel. Definitely on the more tart side of Tripels.

Sample outside Ölbutikken, Copenhagen, while waiting for the Blåbaer-release 160730. Hazy golden beer with decent off-white head. Fruity yeasty aroma, rye bread, floral notes, grapes, some funk. Yeasty floral flavor, grapes, citrus, funky, some spicy notes. A bit odd but it works for me.

Bottle shared at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen post Blåbær release (30/07/2017) - golden pour with white head. Sweet fruity and malty aroma and taste with some citrus fruity notes, light malty, casting sugar sweetness, wheaty and only light yeast nuance, some rye citric spice into the close, style wise not your normal style tripel here, but enjoyable nonetheless.
颜色好神奇，

Pours a bright golden yellow color. Active carbonation throughout the session. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast. Has a light fruity citrus taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.

Thanks Adam.

Golden orange body with a small white head. Funky brett, fruity notes, malt, yeast. Lovely flavor. Bready citrus with loads of Jolly Pumpkin brett funk. Delicious.

Bomber at Jerrys. Brilliant, clear orange-amber with frothy white head, good lacing / Clean nose of orange, banana, resin, spun sugar, earth, rye spice / Medium body, resinous, some sweetness but well balanced by biting hops, bitter finish / Subdued flavors of orange rind, lemon, wildflower, grain / A departure for JP, not as successful, especially as nuanced, as their more established style.

This is not a tripel.
This was poured into a snifter. The appearance was a nice looking hazy amber to orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute leaving some light lacing roaming here and there around the glass. 
The smell had a nice real authentic citrus to spicy rye. A light rye malt enters in as it warms.
The taste was mainly sweet but had a light spicy rye to the flavor. A nice light sweet rye aftertaste accompanies the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Id say that the carbonation was good for me and for the style. Overall, I say this was a pretty good rye beer. This is not a tripel, theres nothing that tells me it has the characteristics of a tripel in the smell and taste.
GABF 2014. Pours a fairly clean golden appearance with a tan head. Some twangy citrus notes along with a spicy element. A little juicy. Kind of bland. Disappointing.

Bottle sampled at GABF 2014. Pours a hazy maber body with thick white head. Aroma is funky fruit and typical JP souring character. Flavors are much more pronounced than the nose. Light, gentle grain in the finish.

Awesome balance. A little heavier on the bretta side than the tripel side. Still some coriander here. Pours golden with good head and lacing. Some grapefruit as well. Finishes with light sweetness and some tangy sense. Good sense. Bottle shared by Ed at Churchkey - thanks!

Bottle courtesy of Ed, at Churchkey. Thanks! Poured a hazy golden color, with a white head. Aroma was light wheat notes, tartness, with some rye spice notes. Flavor had nice yeast character, with some light sour fruits. Very tasty.

Bottle courtesy of Ed, thanks! Slightly hazy golden color, bright white head. Aroma of beautiful white wine, dust, pepper. Taste is really nice, softly sour fruit and dusty barnyards and attic corners. Delicious.

Bottle from Supermarket Liquors. Pours dirty blonde with a decent off-white head and a fruit and rye aroma. There is a hearty pale malt flavor with that slight sourness that is typical to this brewery. The rye adds some nice bitterness and counteracts the usual banana esters from the yeast.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours translucent gold with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is typical tripel with rye spice and an underlying sour note. Med body. Flavor is JP sour with rye spice and fruity esters. Its not sour sour, but it has that signature. Quite nice.

Bottle batch 378. Unclear orange with a very large dirty frothy off white head. Bears little resemblance to a tripel but is a typical Jolly Pumpkin beer, just not as good as they usually are. It has funkyness; barnyard, band aid, pepper, some wood, light earthy, dark bread, light spices, white wine. It starts good with the funky notes and the aroma is fine, but it soon turns harsh and alcoholic and not that pleasant to drink, really. Medium body, medium sweet, light sour and bitter, oily texture, medium/high carbonation. Finish has hot alcohol and lingering funk. To quote Baudelaire; "Kill, kill, kill, kill their motherfucking asses".

750 ml bottle poured a clear tarnished gold with a lasting off white head. Aromas of rye, yeast, pineapple and pear. Palate was medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of rye, fruitiness, light yeast and light spice with a crisp dry lingering fruity finish.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 2/27/2014. Moderate gusher upon opening. Pours moderately hazy/cloudy golden orange color with a 2 finger dense and rocky off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of tart lemon zest, green apple, apricot, orange zest, white wine, hay, straw, grass, herbal, oak, pepper, clove, musty funk, spicy rye, bread, light leather, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of tart fruity/spicy/funky yeast, pale/rye malt, and oak barrel notes; with good strength. Taste of tart lemon zest, green apple, apricot, orange zest, white wine, hay, straw, grass, herbal, oak, pepper, clove, musty funk, spicy rye, bread, light leather, and yeast earthiness. Fair amount of fruity/earthy tartness and yeast spice on the finish; with lingering notes of tart lemon zest, green apple, apricot, orange zest, white wine, hay, straw, grass, herbal, pepper, clove, musty funk, oak, light leather, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and balance of tart fruity/funky/spicy yeast, pale/rye malt, and oak barrel flavors; with a great malt/tartness/yeast spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, lightly prickly, and fairly acidic mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent wild rye saison. All around excellent complexity and balance of tart fruity/funky/spicy yeast, pale/rye malt, and oak barrel flavors; and very smooth and crisp to sip on for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Darker gold pour, big off-white head. Good retention/lace. Aroma of spicy rye, ester, Brett, JP funk. Taste is tart, dusty, spicy rye, light sweetness. Palate is dry, average carbonation, tart finish.

750 ml bottle to tulip (shared by tastybeer). Looks good; a hazy orange with foamy eggshell head. Smells semi-sweet and spicy with notes of brett. Tastes like it smells with a nice, lively mouthfeel and a dry finish. Good beer.

Hazy apricot color. Fine white foam. Loads of berry fruit aroma with touches of pome. Oxidized apple notes with bits of pepper. Very creamy feel. Tangy. Bristly effervescence. Complicating acidity.
 Apple pie flavors.

A slightly hazy light golden with a nice bright white head that sustains well and settles to a film and leaves good lacing. Aroma has light fruit with hay and some pepper. Taste has a bit of tartness with Belgian yeast light fruitines and plenty of rye spiciness and earthiness. Phenolic character and some floral bitterness give the beer a dry finish. Mouthfeel is crisp and medium bodied with high carbonation. Nice spicy tripel with good combination if flavors.

2014 bottle. Pours a hazy golden copper with a fizzy white head. Aroma is tart with some tropical fruit like papaya and mango with a lemon citrus. Has an almost peppermint spiciness at the end from the rye. Taste is earthy with an herbal spiciness and bitterness. Some tartness. A medium dry finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A dark hazy golden orange color. With a coating of white head that settles on surface. Smells of sour citrus, vanilla, all spice, maybe cinnamon, anise, fig, peppermint, banana, pear. Taste is a sour fruit with a spicy rye, a little barnyard, a lot of earthy spiciness, citrus some tea like hop bitter towards the end. Good combination of flavors, plenty of spicy rye, but with some dark fruit and subtle sour notes. Medium mouthfeel and carbonation, slightly dry. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, gusher from the bottle. Hazy orange-red pour with fluffy and lacing white head, aroma brought notes of sour grain, hints of lemon, slight spice, yeast, rye notes into a bit of oak, apricot jam, hints of slight funk. Taste is a mix of oak, lemon, some slight booze into a bit of earth, grain, slight harsh notes into some funk, slight yeast, rye, finishing fairly sweet, slightly tart, funky.

Bottle: The aroma consists of funky brett, lemon peel, candi sugar, dusty yeast notes, sweet citrus, tropical fruit, and faint floral notes. It pours a hazy dark orange with a three finger white head that has pretty good retention before eventually settling to a thick film. The flavor starts with a quick dose of citrus with a touch of candi sugar. The finish has a lot of brett funkiness, lemon, lemon peel, floral notes, and light pepper. As it warms, I get a hint of alcohol. Its light-medium bodied with moderate-lively carbonation with a somewhat soft mouthfeel. Overall, its very tasty, but like a lot of Jolly Pumpkin beers, flavor-wise, this is a Tripel in name only.
Sample at Culmination Fest: Poured a clear yellow with off white head. Aroma was a bit sour and spice. Taste was very spicy rye but not much depth otherwise.
Bottle thanks to mark. Not as sour as a typical JP brew. Nice color and aroma. Not my favorite flavor combo.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Bomber from the TC brewery. Hazy gold with a light head. Tart and fruity. Barnyard and dry.
BOTTLE, FULLER bodied golden orange pour. JP funkiness, tart fruitiness, spree candy, tart & funky tripel. very nice
750 ml bottle. Orange color. Funk in nose. Apricot and honey. Sugar. Lemon zest to finish. Wow. Big twist on the Tripel, for sure.

Clear gold in color... Foamy white head... Aroma of Belgian candi sugar, citrus, light tartness, spice... Flavor is light rye spice on backbone of sticky citrus and toffee... Hint of barnyard funk... Solid 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750 ml. bottle. Pours golden amber with a decent off-white head. Aroma of tart fruit, floral, and spice. Taste is citrus, tart fruit, spice, rye malt, and yeast. Interesting.

Pours dull golden / orange with a nice soapy off-white head. The aroma has banana, rich malt, rye spice, lemon, dry spices, mustiness, caramel and a touch of tartness. It has a medium crisp body with pretty soft carbonation. The taste starts out on the drier side for the style. On the buggy side and some tartness included. Light crackers, citric tartness/spice and rye spice. The finish has a bit of an oakiness even though this doesnt say it was aged in any barrel. Interesting - I really like this one.

Pours a deep thick golden color. With a thick foamy white head. Very funky tart smell. A lot of different flavors all over this. Initially a strong rye flavor that really lasts the whole thing. A lot of bubblegum flavors mixed in with a hop background. Leaves a sour flavor on your lips after every sip. Really a unique beer.

Rated on 5-05-2011 (Bottle Batch 378) This beer pours a huge foamy, fizzy off-white head that is short lived, hazy golden body, fast rising carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is malty, funky, hops, sweet, fruity, spicy, some pepper, light sourness, and tart. The taste is sweet, grassy, pepper, rye, brett, some alcohol, and a dry finish. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is light-medium bodied. This beer is somewhat complex with all the different aromas and flavors taking place. It is a sipping beer and worth trying.
Had a glass on tap at the pub. Delicious, definitely a big boy for a JP, but funky and sour enough to keep it honest.

750 ml bottle

Despite being an immediate gusher this was another excellent production from Jolly Pumpkin. Throwing rye into a tripel did not create some strange novelty. Instead this, kind of like rye IPAs, sets itself apart while retaining the characteristics of a beer true to style.

Aroma / Appearance - After the foam settled the glass was full of caramel bronze liquid. The bubbly foam never really settled 100% but instead left a layer of frosting. Graham crackers, caramel, pretzels, sourdough bread, and rye all contribute to a thick and sweet experience.

Flavor / Palate - Creamy with a tickle of spices this is not subtle. The full bodied mouthfeel contains within a blend of yeast, rye, caramel, and bittersweet chocolate. The long lasting finish gives plenty of time for reflection as well. A well rounded release is definitely a winner if you want something different than your average tripel.

Big thanks to yourefragile for opening up this bottle. Long time want. Served in a Jolly Pumpkin tulip.

Pours a clear light copper with a huge, rocky white head of foam. Very creamy and extremely long lasting. Cap throughout and really nice lacing on the sides of the glass. The nose has a bit of oxidized malt along with a sizable rye presence. Some light pepper and phenols as well.

Flavor begins with rye and a fairly-heavy phenolic presence. A bit of rye in the background, as well as a touch of bread. Body is light, dry, and crisp. A bit bitter. 

Very mild touch of bubblegum in the nose as it warms.

Probably a bit past its prime, and ages different than most Jolly Pumpkin beers. Im not sure what the design was, but this doesnt have any oak, funk, or acidity. As a plain tripel, its not bad, but it isnt anything noteworthy either.
Aroma is fruit, mild spiciness, malts and a hint of hops.  The flavor is fruit/raspberries, mild sour notes, malts and a mild spiciness in the finish.

2nd October 2010Persistent slow gusher - mmmmm! Cloudy amber beer, big white head (no surprise!). Lightly sour nose! Light palate - dry and crisp. Creamy malt with fruit and spice. Acidic and sour fruits - dry and yeasty. Light and airy but its infected I beleive and there is not enough here to make me think its worth a re-rate. Overdry and bolloxed.

In short: An original rustic big blond Belgian ale, like a cranked up Saison, very good
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed probably fresh, pplit three-way, thanks to the Trois-Rivières comedic duo
The look:  Cloudy dark blonde body topped by a medium off-white head
In long: Nose is moderately rye, some dry grass, rustic yeast, musty woody notes (although no wood/barrels here).  Taste is crunchy grainy pale malts, very rustic/barnyard, a bit bretty/leathery, rye presence is very discreet, fruity notes of pears.  Finishes dry.  Drinks more like a big Saison than a Triple per say.  I really liked that beer.  The Beaudelaire series is far from the usual JP signature funky beers but they are just as good.  After that beer we went back to the party, I got drunk again and broke stuff, because when Im drunk I turn perfectly working items into dozens of useless smaller parts.  Basically when Im drunk Im like a reverse MacGyver.

(Bottled, 0.75l, rated 2011-07-22) Hazy copper with HUGE amounts of foam (had to pour the beer in three glasses right away). Sour, berry-malty and sweetish nose. Flavor is sweet and berryish, with lots of sourness and some green apple. Some rye maltiness, too, and alcohol not completely hidden despite the sweetness. Medium body, foamy CO2. All the JP beers are from the same mold, but this is not among the best of them.

Bottle. Slight gusher. Amber pour with frothy dirty white head. Aroma is very rye forward, tons of brett, JP funk, some belgian yeast, quite spicey and yeasty. Taste is tart, lots of grain, tripel yeast, bready, a tad of alcohol. Palate is good, full bodied with prickly carbonation, long finish.

(Bottle, 0.75 l - batch 378, at Pikkulintu, 20110708) Gusher. The beer poured amber and a little bit hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had sourness, spices, fruitiness and rye bread. Palate was medium bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, fruitiness, sourness, sweetness, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste was sour, fruity and bitter. Not the best JP brew.

Bottle 750 ml batch 378
 Aroma:  gusher , hazed amber with frothy pillow like top. Sticky lace. 
 Appearance:  frontal dryness , leafy sweetness with some tartness on side. Bit of funk and black pepper. 8-
 Palate / Taste:   Frontal bouncy carbonation. Sugars with brown kind as main one . Easy going m, mild with leafy green top. Finishing with alcohol. Interesting brew.

Kens bottle, lovely stuff.  Malty aroma.  Enormous amount of foam in my pour.  Wild wild, love the brett, good malt and yeast, and a little rye edge.  A minority in tha it tastes better than it smells.Very smooth, lots of head even 15 minutes in.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2nd ES/CS Beer Tasting. (thanks XA). Deep goldeny orange/amber colour with a small off-white head. Aroma is spices, some tart wood, mild rye as well as some yeasty notes. Flavour is a bunch of fruits, some tart fruits, wood, mild ryebready and bready notes. Rather sour/tart wooden notes towards the finish.
Bottle. High creamy and long lasting white head. Hazy orange body. Powerful grapefruit pine vinegar aroma. Hoppy fruity spicy flavor. Low carbgonation. Long bitter aftertaste.

Hazy amber pour with a rocky white head and drippy lace..  This slowly gushed.  Aroma is light clove, dark fruit and sour mash.   Cotton candy, doughnut, sour grape and green apple.  Tart and kinda slick finish

Sample from a 750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours an orange amber color with a huge pillowy white head.  The nose was floral, somewhat spicy with some of the standard JP funk.  The flavor has some citrus, mild herbal spiciness, with a finish that is especially dry and grassy.  A slight burn to this as it goes down.

batch 378 consumed 8/4/10.

hazy. dirty blond with a huge speckled white head. overcarbonated. tons of clingy foam.

it smells like a roll of life savers candy... pineapple, slate, pale malt, flowers, yeast, spice and straw.

the flavor is very floral... lots of pineapple, straw and cement. really dry but quite malty.

the body is almost thick... yet prickly and not over done considering dryness.

neat. 9/4/8/4/15

22 April 2011, bottle w/ cgarvieuk. med yellow, faintly cloudy. really tart. yeast and tart cherries. i wouldnt have called this a tripel by any stretch. thin body, fizzy. interesting. faint tart cherry, some dry earthy yeast. interesting.

bottle at home ... amber ... huge whte bubbly head ... funk barnyard saison ... sour nose ... light zazty ... light soft sour ... clean fresh and easy ... again light funky ... light body ... ok but not my thing

Courtesy of Philippe (Bov)Explosive bottle, uncontrolled fermentation. Hazy amber color. Bretty aroma, lightly herbal, minty. After most of the carbonation is gone, its quite smooth; the malt is more evident than in other beers, while the Brett is less; a bit fruity, with decent bitterness; woody final, a bit astringent. Good.
Big floral and lemon pepper nose. The taste is very hoppy, fairly tart, with pepper, lemons, flowers and honey malts. Very dry finish. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a hazy and dark amber beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, fruit, dried fruit and some notes of acidity. The flavor is close to the nose. The palate is dry. Overall a good beer.
Bottle @ Odense tasting. Hazy amber body with a large white head. Aroma is sourish, berries, alcohol and light peppar notes. Flavor is alcohol, light sourish, yeast and fruit.
Pours cloudy amber with a beige head, chunks. Flavour is caramel, acidic notes, fruit, brett and apple. Flavour is caramel, brett, alcohol, fruit and apple.
Bottle @ Odense Tasting, December 2010. Batch 378. Pours hazy orange with a full white head and lacings. Funk, yeast, oak, orange, brett and hops. Tasty, crisp and dry. Ohh Yes . .

Hazy amber with a big and lasting, fluffy white head. Intense and unique aroma of funk, spice - lots of pepper - wood character, and some exotic fruit, especially pineapple. Dry and spicy flavour with wood character and lots of tannin and pepper for refreshing result.

Bottle, Batch #378. Medium to deep slightly hazy orange body, thick, puffy buff head. Sweet, fruity nose with pear, caramel, bread dough, and spice. Doughy body, plump for a Jolly Pumpkin beer, with light fruit, brown sugar, and spice, also plummy, with warming alcohol. Tart and tannic in the finish, building after a few sips, but thankfully never overwhelming the palate. This beer was a gusher, but I am happy that I was able to salvage most of the bottle.

750ml bottle. Not a gusher but a creeper - I was warned to chill this one down, which probably helped!. Poured a medium and cloudy amber color with a large sized, frothy off white head. Some large particles. Aromas of yeast, spices, some rye, and fruitiness. Tastes of rye, spices, fruity, and yeast. Light sour finish.

Bottle. The appearnce is spectacular! Huge, huge creamy and long lasting head. Definitely 5/5! The rest of the beer is not that good. Kind of boring for being a Jolly Pumpkin beer. Sour, dry and with a lot of rye.

Bottle.
Pours golden brown with a huge and long lasting cloud-looking head, impressingly firm!

Fruity and semi sweet with lots of rye in the taste.
LCBS 2010.  Lots of earthy spice, yeast, honey, light caramel, rye spice.  Flavor is a bit hot, some light hop, candi sugar, malty sweetness.  Light woody notes.  Interesting.

75 cl bottle from Ølbutikken in Copenhagen. NIce art work on the lable and appearently "a breath of air from the wings of madness." Batch 378. Pretty alive when uncaped - keep a glass ready. Pouring a deep moisty orange with a massive foamy head. Quite good looking.A fresh aroma with the perfumic caracteristics of the trippel without getting too much. Notes of apricots, walnuts, rye, brett and some fruity stuff. Taste is fresh with bitter notes and some perfumic notes. The finish is not worth writing about - its not there. The palate is medium to light. Normaly Im of the opinion that it should be left for the belgians but actually I think this one works out quite well. Very drinkable and pretty balanced

Aroma is lactic, spicy, some 
Taste is very lactic, some spices, a touch of rye, lots of alcohol, some hop bitterness.  
Well, to be honest, I am not getting much out of this.  Alcohol, a bit of spices, low hop bitterness, and lactic sourness.  
Eh.

Bottle at RBSG Grand Tasting 10. Pours a coppery-blond with fluffy head. Plenty of fizz. Nose is spicy and full. Quite bready with a nice phenolic overtone that lends a sweetness. booze hides out in the background. On taste, the rye keeps it spicy and dry. full bodied and alcohol is well hidden. some cloves. Well fermented. Finishes dry. Very tasty stuff.

Bottle from splax23. Batch 378. Dirty gold color and pours with a booming head but not a gusher. Fruity esters in the aroma along with cloves, mild spice, flowers, and the trademark JP funk. The flavors are spicy and dry. Fruity notes; tangerine, sharp citrus. This has some grainy notes and a little bit of the rye comes through as well that I didnt really get in the aroma. Lots of funky yeast provides another element but I expect nothing else from JP. Very dry in the finish with a little alcohol sneaking in there. A very nice beer. Tastes more like a Saison than a Triple to me and Ive got no problem with that at all.
Bottle. Pours a hazy pale amber color with a longlasting off-white head. Has a fruity malty yeasty spicy aroma. Fruity malty yeasty spicy flavor. Has a sweetish malty fruity spicy yeasty finish.
Bottle. Golden-orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is brett, malt, spices. Flavour is hop, yeast, fruit, brett, lemon. Nice beer.

A: The pour is a slightly hazy golden color with some hints of orange and amber. The head is a tower of white foam that takes some time to settle down to a level that allows drinking.

S: A wonderful spice note is present right away, that seems to be the rye with maybe a hint of pepper or just some yeasty esters. A light funkiness along with some citrus zest and a hint of green fruits.

T: The rye and yeast esters provide a really great spice note along with some bready malts that are the base of this beer. A gentle funk character with some hay and straw, and a great dry, bretty quality. A lightly tart lemon flavor and some hints of green apple.

M: The body is medium with a very full carbonation that sort of tickles the tongue.

D: The last couple Jolly Pumpkin special releases have really been fantastic. This one was no exception and I really enjoyed this beer.

BottleRBSG 2010 Pours cloudy amber with a small, creamy, white head. Fantastic, permanent retention. Im really picking up some nice funk in the otherwise acidic, spicy, herbal aroma. Medium to full-bodied and very creamy with tickling carbonation. The flavor is perfectly balanced between bitter and sweet. A bit funky and tart. The lengthy, bitter finish is also a touch dry.

Had this while camping at BCTC this year.  Pours a hazy milky orange brown with a thin white head.  Light spicy rye, soft caramel, and sweet fruit with a light Jolly Pumpkin funk on the nose.  Spicy, toast and rye with some alcohol behind it.  Long rye finish, sweet and spicy.

from Erzbierschof.ch - hazy reddish-brown in colour and with a solid persistent beige foam; aroma of dust, apples and vinegar; creamy palate and medium-bodied, unexpected notes of cork in the finish along with sourish, nutty and creamy notes

750 ml bottle, courtesy beerlando. This one pours a cloudy golden yellow color and topped by a thick, well retained head of off white foam. Thick rings of lace stick to the glass as the head recedes. The aroma shows notes of spicy rye grains, dry fruits, lemon peel, and the classic JP funk from the yeast. The flavor follows and is quite spicy with notes of lemon peel, pepper, and rye to go with the funky yeast. The fruits are there, but quite dry, which is nice. Medium bodied, crisp, and dry with balanced carbonation and a nice spicy finish. This is a nice brew and much better than any standard tripel.

Bottle shared at RBSG 2010. Poured clear brown with an average frothy white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex funky toasted malt and yeast aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a complex good beer.

Sampled with compliments of a kindly fellow rate-beerian at the RBSG 2010 grand tasting. Pours a hazy blond almost grayish with a good head and some lace. The aroma is lemon rind with some earthy notes and some sweet fruit. The flavor i s dry and slightly smoky with some good sour and tart notes and a bit of spiciness.

Bottle, 75cl, at Mikkeller. A hazy, golden-orange beer with a dense, off-white head. Bretty nose with pale malts. Fruity flavor with pale malts and brett. Both aroma and flavor has moderate influence from the brett, some barnyard-ish and lemon-ish notes can be found. Its full-bodied and effervescent, with little influence from the wood. An easy drinkable tripel, hiding the alcohol very well, and its also quite tasteful. 100506
Bottled 75cl. Brettanomyces throughout. Not bothered to write too much, because I am talking on the phone with grandma and rating and drinking this beer. Delicious.

Hazy dark golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of honey, citrus, wild yeast, wood, vanilla, rye, and wild yeast.  Taste of citrus fruits, light spices, vanilla, toffee, and a wild finish.

Bottle. Totally gushing! Cloudy orange with a fluffy white head. The aroma is very fruity and a bit acidic tart. Notes of coriander, sweet caramel, yeast and berries. Fruity and tart flavour with a nice acidic kick to balance the sweet caramel. I can taste the alcohol but it also complements the sweetness. Tart bitter fruity finish. Different but delicious.

Poured a hazy copper brown.  Shared by someone generous at the RBSG grand tasting 10 (michigan!).  Aroma was dusty brett, hint of rye, spice and a hint of fruit.  Taste was more brett on the backend, nice balancing rye and herbal bitterness, light malt sweetness with a hint of oak.  Nicely balanced beer.

cloudy brown, smooth white head.
dry and sour aroma
flavor is sweet soursh, hoppy , a bit unbalanced.

Bottle thanks to ditmier Batch #378. Pours out cloudy golden topped with a white head. Aroma was of sweet pit fruit, belg yeast, spice, and light malts. Taste was all of the aroma along with a little more light malts, hops, and rye. A little wood and bitterness on the end.
Mild JP funk on the nose with spicy aromas.  Pours a pale amber with a thick white head.  Mild funk, rye flavors, nice spicy flavors.  Very nice!

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a lazing fluffly off-white head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, malt, citrus, straw, and dust. The flavor is sweet with notes of citrus, brettanomyces, alcohol, and over ripe fruits. Thanks myself for sharing.
750ml bottle @ Mikkeller. Hazy orange with a fine white head. Aroma is quite light fruity and slightly acidic. Flavor is refreshing fruity, dry, light malty, spices, yeast with a hint of  brett.

Thanks turdferguson for sharing. Pours a cloudy orange with a profuse crackling yellow head. Nose is spicy, a tad dry, peppery, rye, citrus rind, mild sweetness, estery. Flavor is peppery and dry, some juniper, rye, pink grapefruit and hibiscus. Palate is very dry and zesty with some citrus rind bitterness.

Bottled. Light amber coloured. Unclear. dense light beige head. Aroma of yeast, sweetness, fruits, spice, perfume. Flavour of yeast, sweetness, fruits and spice. Light grapy touch. Medium to full bodied. Yeasty and grpy end.
Cloudy amber with a large off white head. Slightly hoppy aroma with yeasty and fruity notes. Flavour had ripe fruits, hops, yeast and malty notes. Finished dry and bitter.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a cloudy deep golden with a huge and lively rough white head leaving some lacework. Aroma is slightly tart, very appley - perhaps a vague whiff of Brett?. Medium body, fruity and lots of yeast and somewhat rough phenols. Vaguely tart finish. 240610

Bottle 750ml.Clear medium amber color with a large to huge, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, rye notes, malty, flowers, pink roses, light wood, spices, fresh, moderate to light heavy yeasty, fruity, leather. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dry dusty like chocolate pudder, spices, fresh. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100618]

Flaske: Meget sjov øl. Rugen er meget dominerende i både smag, duft og farve. Orange øl med et fint skumhoved. Proteinklumper i bunden. Duften er lækker med en tand jolly i den. Smagen er kompleks men ikke helt balanceret, for megen rug. Fin mundfylde men ikke helt oppe og ringe.

Gushing bottle at home.
Hazy orange coloured with a huge but fast disappearing white head.
Fruity aroma of yeast, spices, alcohol, oak and brett with notes of barnyard.
Fruity flavour of spices, marzipan and alcohol with notes of brett and oak.
Spicy and alcoholic finish.
Too alcoholic.
Hazy yellow with big white head. Aroma of citrus hops, oak, spice and clove. Tart, Flemish aspect to it. Zesty, herbal flavor with pepper, wood, clove and lemon.

750 ml bottle; thanks Brandon!! A mild gusher with huge foamy eggy white head; aromas of grapefruit, bready spice, brett and lemons; hazy body with dry finish and lemony flavors; bready with fruity zing and some huskiness; pretty high on the spice chart and that takes away from the drinkability a bit; dry, spice, brett, lemons with fizzy mouthfeel; pretty husky and doesnt really come together for me

75cl bottle shared by illidurit.   Hazy orange color with a big frothy head.   Funky, dusty aroma with a leathery brett character, some honey, oaky spice, spiced apple pie and some mulled cider.   The flavor has a nice fruitiness with some pear and apple, some bretty funk, honey, and warming alcohol in the finish.   It finishes a little sweet, which its only detractor.   Not sweet in an absolute sense, but it sticks out compared to the rest of the components of the beer.   Highly carbonated and airy, but very soft at the same time.   Overall a very nice beer, but the aroma definitely comes off better than the flavor.

Bottle courtesy of iceicebaby. Pours a hazy dark orange color with a huge fluffy khaki head. Aroma is a first lemony, then appley, then spices like nutmeg and clove come into play, giving it a fleeting apple pie character. Flavor is nice and funky, really bretty and with some phenolics as well. Probably the closest thing to Orval other than Orval that Ive tasted. There are lots of parallels: orange color, fruity aroma, bretty flavor, bone dry finish, high-but-soft carbonation. The mouthfeel is spot-on Orval. Really not much in the tripel department. Definitely not an ester-forward beer. But thats fine with me. Orval is incredible, and this sorta-clone is great too.

750ml bottle thanks to Orlando crew. Pours a hazy golden color with a big white head. Nose is sour, funk, citrus, slight fruit notes as well. Flavor is the same as the nose but not as sour as I thought it was going to be. Refreshing flavors with the citrus, funk, also get hints of pineapple in the flavor. Nice dry sour finish to it.

750ml bottle, batch #378.  Gorgeous packaging.  The body is a very cloudy, glowing, yellowish-golden hue with a dense, lasing head of rocky, off-white froth.  Thick, solid sheets of lace are well pronounced, clinging hard to the glass.  The first whiff draws a smile, as it reveals that familiar, comforting, and unmistakable JP funk.  Further contemplation shows notes of spicy rye grain, peppery lemon peel, light coriander, and ultra-dry, fruity, spicy yeast.  Flavors show more of the same, again quite spicy with notes of pepper, lemon peel, caraway, and rye grain, all enveloped in the standard woody, bretty house yeast.  The palate is very dry, crisp, and parching, which is a welcome departure from standard tripel fare.  Very nice brew.  Pretty much exactly what I thought Ron Jeffries would do with a tripel.

750ml bottle courtesy of Fiver29  thanks John!  Pours dark gold with a gigantic head.  The nose is light barnyard, lemon zest and funk.  The taste is funk, citrus peels, peppery yeast and an astringent finish, most likely from the rye.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Interesting brew for sure.
Bottled @ Copenhagen 2010. Clear orange color, big rocky head. Aroma of spicy fruit, hint of marzipan. Belgian-like. Bit dry, bit fruity, cherry? Ok brew.

Bottle @ Mikkeller bar. The aroma has yeast and is intense citric. Bit hazy, copper-orange coloured beer with an off-white, big head. The taste is yeasty, citric, has apples and spice (pepper, and others). Bit malty background. Nice.

Courtesy of SuzyGreenberg.  Pours with loads of light tan foam and copper to amber hued body as well as small dark floaties.  The aroma has tart notes to go along with a sweet apple like sense and dark fruitiness off in the background. The taste starts with a rush of sweet fruit and a Brett like tartness in equal quantities and then moving more tart and then a bit more spicy and fruity into the finish.

(on bottle) Clear rusty red, gushing white head. Interesting aromas, stricking as both withheld, yet an intense tartness. Allmost no carbonating left, while drinking, odd for a gushing beer. Still retained in flavours, dry hay, champagne, cork, zinging appels. Slight barley finish, with a tad of alcohol warmth.
Bottle @ Mikkeller bar. Orange, red colored brew. Fruity, yeasty aroma. Flavor is fruits, yeast, very smooth, light sour.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  Super gusher.  The look is cloudy, big foamy off white head.  The smell is tart, fruits, rye, and grains.  The taste is grainy, fruits, tart, rye, and dusty.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours a nice, clear orange with a big, frothy, off-white head. Lovely aroma of oak, vanilla, spicy rye and sweet pilsner malts. Great, prickly carbonation, good dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has green apples, wood, pineapple, rye, spiciness, vanilla. Very dry finish with a hint of pepper. Very delicious.
A delicious beer.  Slightly sweet up front with a slight tang from the rye.  The finish is crisp & dry.  As it warms, the sweetness mellows and there is a touch of oakiness as well as some sourness.
Cloudy, hazy orange yellow with puffy meringue like head.  Notes of funk, cotton candy, pineapple, oak.  Nice balance.  Yum.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 Bottle at MikkellerBAR thanks to yngwie and friends. 
cloudy amber - White head. Fruity, bretty, peppery, soapy, berries, sharpness, (batch 377).

2010 Bottle, Batch 378 - Respect to mibirder for the hookup, thanks!! - Pours a super hazy orange with a massive sandy tan head...aroma is plenty of spicy oak, rye tinted funk, dust, some light fruit sweetness as well...flavour is similar, earty, dusty brett, lemon tartness, rye spice...Im happy to see JPs barrel program just keep pushing the envelope...

(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy golden-taupe body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of herbs, florals, grain, earth, light horseblanket, rye, and grass.  Flavor of florals, herbs, Belgian yeast, citrus, some pepper, brett, and grass with a dry finish.

(bottle - 750 ml) Popped and overflowed immediately upon opening. This happens with pretty much every Jolly Pumpkin beer weve tried. Dark orange in color with a mountain of white foam that lasts forever and a day. Earthy and spicy aroma with hints of oak, funk, rye and fruit. Lots of spice and dry rye characteristics at the start of the flavor with some deep and sweet oak notes, a fruity followup and a lightly peppery and dry finish. Tons of different flavors and they all blend really well together.

Big oak and funky sour notes. Hints of earth and light rye notes, some banana. Murky orange golden pour, fizzy and creamy head. Fruity and spicy up front, somewhat tart and with a good deal of funk. Im picking up some banana bread. Oak, funk, and alcohol notes. Pepper as well. Lingering pepper in the finish. Lively carbonation, tartness lingers. Woody and dry in the finish.

750, capped. thanks ben! pours a cloudy dark amber with a big fizzy white head that sticks around. tart green apple nose with a little bit of white pepper in there. creamy medium fizzy body. tangy green apples and white pepper on the mid palate with a little bit of pepper on the finish.

750ml sent by Hoppymeal, thanks Derek!  Opens with a bit of gush.  Big, huge, off white loose head.  Tart lemon, peach, vinegar, pepper, spice, touch of bubblegum.  Tart peach and lemon, good amount of spice, some estery apple and maybe banana, oak, pepper finish.  Interesting stuff.

Gusher. Murky brown body, frothy head very typical of JP. Almost smells like a tripel. Alcohol feel is kicked up a notch. Medium sweetness, a lot of funk, and in fact this does taste much like every other JP beer. I tried this because I was curious, but this doesnt really do it for me.

750 mL bottle.  Foams over upon opening, then pours a hazy amber with a large off-white head.  Funky sour aroma with apple and clove.  Flavor has quite a bit of bretty funk with just a little tartness, some spices, bits of fruit notes, and hints of the rye used here.  Very dry.  I kind of wish the sourness was more pronounced in the flavor, but this is a job well done.

Bottle thanks to ? Pours a murky yellow, straw golden color with a fizzy bubbly creamy head.  Nice JP funk in the aroma, fuller creamy aroma, pool water, nutty, alcohol which is odd for JP, oaky creaminess.  Flavor is quite odd, medicinally sweet, nutty, spicy, medium crisp lactic sourness. Fizzy carbonation, medium body.  Strange.

3-2-10 bottle at JP Cafe. Cloudy golden, orange highlights, huge head, plenty of carbonation. Aroma has a heavy dose of rye up front, really woody, sweaty horse, hints of fruit. Flavor is dominated by the rye spiciness, with hints of wood and fruit, not much else. Mouthfeel is spritzy like 7-up, subtracts a little. Even letting it breath for quite awhile, still retains the carbonation. Solid triple, just not a style Im really into.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  cloudy yellow with a white head.  yeast, dried fruits, light alcohol, wood and a light sourness.  nice on the palate, flavors of yeast, spices, dried fruits, wood, and a smooth tartness.

So I take the cork out and immediately get foam all over my hands.  I set the bottle in the sink and waited an hour - it was still gushing (albeit slowly)!  I ended up taking a little sip from the bottle and dumping the rest.  A big waste of $15.  At least it smelled nice.

Watch out, its a gusher.  Pours burnt orangish with a huge rocky white head.  Aroma of spice, funk, and light apple juice, somewhat sweet.  Flavor is somewhat spicey, somewhat meaty with a nice funk, light bitterness.  The rye is a nice component to this style, as is the funk.  Effervescent mouthfeel, finishes with some hops.  Pretty ridiculously awesome.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured cloudy yellow with a white head.  aroma was sour, tart, and peach.  flavor was pretty much the same with a light body and high carbonation.

(750ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) When we opened this bottle it gushed upwards like Mount Saint Helens. Even with more than half the bottle gone it was still eclipsing the top! Murky orange with huge head. Nose of sour cherry, oak barrel, and apricot. Taste of white wine, oak, earth, unsweet peach. Finish is very alcoholic, spicy, but well carbonated light a champagne.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 Enjoyed at Ann Arbor Jolly Pumpkin bar. Bottle. Sweet aroma with Belgian candy. Flavor is semi-.......Apparently I had a tech glitch while rating this...Will update as soon as my other bottle arrives.  Numbers are accurate however.  Nice brew.

When I popped the cap off it hissed so loudly I thought I was going to be wearing some beer.  Luckily I was standing over the sink and was able to pour some out of the bottle right away as the foam simply gushed out of the glass.  Each pour had 3/4 foam and 1/4 beer.  The beer was cloudy amber color with off white head. Once it settled down the aroma had a nice woody aroma and some subtle funky notes.  Obviously mouthfeel was real stinging due to high carbonation.  Way too much carbonation for me.  So much in fact I kept burping with each sip.  Flavor was actually pretty good.  Some tart and funk led to a spicy dry finish.  If it wasnt for the over the top fizz in this it would be way more enjoyable.

An absolutely absurd gusher thanks to bu11zeye. This thing gushed slowly, but was still pushing foam over the brim with about an eighth of its contents remaining. Pours with a large, foamy, head over a murky brown body. Aroma of brett, phenolic, rye, and grassy. Taste is sour, tart and very dry. Lively bubbles. Interesting.

Poured some of a 750ml bottle into a tulip glass.  It poured rather clear with an obvious carbonation and lacing up the side of the glass.  Very aromatic.  It tastes very much as it smells.  Has that funky Belgium twist with some hops.  I just think it would be best left at that.  But the beer has some citrus sourness that I did not enjoy.

22 fl oz bottle, courtesy of cloudskipper. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry and citric. citric and dry brett to hoppy mild spiced base flavour. Bitter and slight citric with a light barnyard note. Bitter and bone dry finish.

750mL bottle at Woodshop 5.0, courtesy of cloudskipper. Thanks, Chris! POurs a murky, deep yellow color; medium-bubbled off-white head with good retention and solid lacing. Nicely bretty aroma, lots of complex esters and yeast character here; crackers, toasty, hints of alcohol. Medium body: creamy presence in the mouth; following the nose: lots of creamy yeast, crackers, well-developed / non-acidic brett character; a very toasty, Belgian-style beer; solidly bretty. Lasting dry finish: toasty, hints of grains, lingering crackers; nicely dry.

Pours a murky darker amber, a huge cakey offwhite head that laces excellently, wont die. Aromas are a nice melange of floral and citrusy hops, a touch of mellow rye malts, the hops take hold with a decent funky brett quality, a touch of Belgian spice. Fruity. Initial is medicinal, some fruity esters and a faint spice, vanilla, with a decent funky brett, bubblegum amoxicillan, lighter on the palate, the rye seems to conflict with the beer. A touch of boozy heat, very belgian slanted, with some light funk and sweet esters. Interesting, a touch of amoxicillan kids liquid, nuts, fruits, slightly sweet malts. Ok. Interesting is the key word with this brew.

Ale absurd... Pours a cloudy orange caramel brown with a hefty soapy white head... Aroma of earthy sweet and medicinal spiciness as well as orange peel... Flavors of lively and spritzy earth and citrus. Little too dry and effervescent
750ml, pours hazy auburn with white head. Nose of cookie, rye, herbs, and phenolic. flavors of rye, caramel, spicy yeasty, medicinal. Spritzy carb. Odd brew.

Gusher bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with a MASSIVE, rocky white head.  The aroma is a nice blend of spice, banana, clove, damp wood, slight black pepper and that distinct Jolly Pumpkin funk.  The flavor is bold and spicy with the rye pepperyness standing out much more than the aroma.  The Belgian esters and oak aging blend to make a nice luscious earthy fruit character with hints of banana creme and clove.  The body is creamy and quite full and that massive amount of carbonation comes across quite soft and smooth.

The cap comes off safely enough, but I get this into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip and end up with seven fingers of foam that continuously spews foam over the sides.  Finally settles down enough to take away from the sink and I have a picturesque tall head that sits about an inch above the rim of my glass.  In the bottle the beer was actually pretty clear, but after pouring, the beer is a reddish, darkish amber hue that shows a hazed, pink-orange, amber hue when held up to the light.  As the head slowly subsides it leaves a nice, layered, lacing pattern on the sides of my glass and the head is very structure forming mesas that have quite some staying power.  Visually, you cant ask for much more from a beer of this type.  The aroma is musty with a woody peppery note, a faint tartness (a touch of lemon perhaps) and a grassy-earthy grain note that dominates the finish.  Very rustic and earthy smelling, but also bone dry smelling, this is a very nice smelling beer.

Light, a touch fizzy (it has sat long enough in my glass that it has loss much of the excess carbonation) and it has a dry, grassy grain finish as well as a touch of phenolic clove and a very faint tartness (much of which could just come from the wheat).  There are some light apple and pear notes here, but this is dry enough of a beer that it is very subtle.  Earthy, slightly musty notes perhaps signal a touch of Brettanomyces character, but this is very faint and only at the beginning stages of funkification.  There is a very grounded, earthy, woody pepper note here that is only lightly spicy.  The malt actually almost has a savoriness to it that is brought out by the dryness; there is a nice pale grain cracker note, a touch of hay and some freshly threshed wheat notes.  Much of the spiciness is from the wild fermentation character (even if it is a touch tame); there is definitely quite a bit of phenolics in this beer, it is a touch clove like, but mostly a bit plastic like, or even a touch solvent like, butt this last is definitely quite faint.  The oak plays a definite supporting role here, it is almost hard to even recognize underneath the steady, earthy funkiness, but it does accentuates a light, overall spiciness, the touch of woody character, as well as some tannic astringency towards the finish.  The texture of this beer is definitely light, this is a beer meant to be quaffed, but it doesnt come off as being overly thin as there is a touch of malt viscosity to this brew; some of the oak derived tannins also contribute a bit to the weight of this brew.

This has the perfect amount of funkiness to be classified as a Farmhouse ale; the funk lightly accentuates the rustic grain and yeast-fermentation character.  This is a Farmhouse ale for the late spring or early Autumn as it is a touch more malty and textured than a pale, light Summer Saison.

750 ml bottle.  Foggy orange brown with a lacy off-white head.  Poured out  half the bottle into two glasses before the foaming settled down.  Wild stuff.  Nose is yeast and lemon candy with floral hints.  Medium light with prominent sudsy carb.  Taste is hay, lemon peel, melon and apricot.  Finishes with peach pit and lime zest.  Crisp and very sessionable.  Really good farmhouse brew.

750mL Bottle. Aroma is a spicy amalgam of mulled cider, cooked coconut and seared pineapple, light, tropically floral and spicy. Carbonation furiously mixes a murky orange liquid beneath a fluffy, quite tall pear-flesh-colored head. The flavor is funky and unique. Heavily herbal and a bit meaty, with some sharp spiciness. Hard to parse and very muddled. Some fig paste, white cumin, sandalwood, incense, dried maple leaves, and white grape must. Sharp on the tongue and a bit alcoholic. A bite of generic hop bitterness hits me on the way down. The finish produces a half sweet/half savory spice and herb finish that lingers. While Im incredibly grateful to have an opportunity to try this, Im not sure its JPs finest effort.

Bottle at the Brewpub. Poured a hazy amber with a huge yellowish eggshell head. Aroma was full of sour notes with undertones of floral and sweet fruits. Flavor began sour with a lemony flavor, but transitioned in to more of a rye hoppy flavor for the finish. Very dry on the the tongue. The transition in the flavor is a bit awkward, but other than that, a good beer.

Bottle.   Pours a very hazy copper color with a humongous white head.   The head looks like egg whites beat to stiff peaks.   Aroma is floral, yeasty, some barnyard notes, lemon zest, oak.   Flavor is peppery hops, floral notes, lemon zest, some citrus, more oak.   Palate is medium light, highly carbonated, finished tart, dry, and bitter.   Another great one from Ron.
